comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: No javadoc - no indication of what a "checkbox image" is, and which one is returned.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
Do we need to expost the checkbox, shouldnt we just hide this and provide a method as follows:
dcp_Absence_AbsenceServicing.setCheckbox(actualTimeReportingData);

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: From previous experience we would normally keep this kind of API as it allows use to select / deslelect (if editing a previously selected checkbox) with ease. With your suggestion, I would have to add a boolean to that api too to say whether it was actually selected or not i.e. allow for the flexibility as previously mentioned OR add another api to allow the deselection of a previously selected checkbox. Is that not overkill?

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Filipe migrated this to createChildAbsencePeriod() http://iedev317.development.fineos.com/reviewboard/r/76709 because we need to make sure that Actuals are not associated to a leave request (otherwise we would need to update many absence periods listviews around the application). Back to the question, this is needed because we're reusing the intake's popup which create the object and set the leave request on it, I've done this way to have minimum changes on the widget to not impact Intake.

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Question: Should this be in a XXXPersistenceService class? I dunno when you use the persistence version vs when you use this one so ...

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: I guess one simple explanation is: If the service merely exposed a way to access setters it's a persistence service. If the service also exposes some sort of business logic we drop the persistence. This is the theory in my opinion but I'm sure you'll find some examples were that rule is broken :)

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
As for previous enum interaction, this is already implemented in com.fineos.absence.common.EnumUtils.getFilteredEnumInstancesName().
Never write anything like this in a widget - you should get a "feel" for things that are really generic and think "this must exist somewhere else". Only as a last resort should you write it yourself, and even at that, it should then be placed in a re-useable class.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment:
Not an issue but usually I don't use InjectionHelper in Widgets because the framework injection works here.
I usually use it in services because services can be used in Rules or others componentes where the framework doesn't work.
